title: Tropical Storm Ernesto tracker : Latest forecast as storm moves over Leeward Islands , toward Puerto Rico
message:
A satellite image shows Tropical Storm Ernesto over the Atlantic Ocean and moving west-northwest toward the Lesser Antilles on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were also in effect Tuesday for Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands.
The storm is traveling over the Leeward Islands and is expected to move near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by Tuesday evening.
Meanwhile, tropical storm warnings are in effect for the following areas:St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Antigua, Barbuda and AnguillaGuadeloupeSt. Martin and St. BarthelemySint MaartenBritish Virgin IslandsU.S. Virgin IslandsPuerto RicoVieques and CulebraA tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected within the specified areas within 36 hours.
While southeastern Puerto Rico could see 6 to 8 inches of rainfall, with maximum amounts of 10 inches, northeastern Puerto Rico could see 2 to 4 inches of rain.

title: Tracking tropics | Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in the Atlantic , warnings issued from Leeward Islands to Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto could strengthen and become hurricanePartly sunny with few storms possible.
RALEIGH, N.C. (WTVD) -- Ernesto remains a Tropical Storm Tuesday morning after forming in the Atlantic Ocean Monday.
The storm is expected to bring tropical conditions to the Leeward Islands, Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by Wednesday, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).
The storm comes days after Debby moved up the East Coast unleashing tornadoes and flooding in multiple states.
Hurricane Debby, which entered North Carolina as a tropical storm, weakened into a tropical depression, has moved out of the U.S. over the weekend.

title: Maps show Tropical Storm Ernesto path and forecast as it intensifies en route to Puerto Rico
message:
Hurricane watches were in effect for the U.S. Virgin Islands, Culebra, Vieques and the British Virgin Islands.
Tropical storm warnings were also in effect for those places, as well as in Puerto Rico, St. Kitts and Nevis, Montserrat, and Anguilla, St. Martin and St. Barthelemy and Sint Maarten.
Tropical storm warnings are issued when forecasters expect tropical storm conditions to impact an area within 36 hours, but meteorologists said at 2 p.m.
ET on Tuesday that tropical storm conditions were expected to begin in the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by nighttime, and potentially even sooner than that.
The same peak surge forecast could materialize in the U.S. Virgin Islands, including St. Thomas, St. John and St. Croix, and in the British Virgin Islands.

title: When will Puerto Rico , Virgin Islands feel Tropical Storm Ernesto ? Follow the track
message:
Hurricane watches were issued across the Caribbean on Tuesday ahead of a stronger Tropical Storm Ernesto, including for the Virgin Islands and two islands that are part of Puerto Rico.
Here’s what to know:Where is Tropical Storm Ernesto now?
Forecasters say the islands will feel Ernesto’s tropical storm conditions Tuesday through Wednesday, with hurricane conditions possible for the Virgin Islands, Culebra and Vieques.
This is where the hurricane center expects the system will strengthen into a hurricane.
The U.S. east coast will likely see dangerous surf and rip current conditions Friday through the weekend, according to the hurricane center.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto gaining momentum as it approaches Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto has moved into the Caribbean Sea as it packs heavy rain and damaging winds and approaches the U.S. territories of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
First, it will reach the Leeward Islands Tuesday, before proceeding to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands later in the day, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect for the entire area, the NHC said.
RELATED STORY | NOAA expects 'extraordinary' 2024 Atlantic hurricane seasonAs the storm approaches, Puerto Rico has activated the National Guard and canceled classes at the start of the public school year, according to The Associated Press.
Bermuda could also get hit with the storm later in the week.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto tracking toward Leeward Islands , Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto a little stronger as it passes just south of St. Kitts, NevisTAMPA, Fla. - Newly formed Tropical Storm Ernesto is tracking toward the Leeward Islands and Puerto Rico as it continues to gather strength, according to the NHC.
According to the National Hurricane Center, Ernesto is passing just south of St. Kitts and Nevis.
A hurricane watch has been issued for the Virgin Islands, Vieques, and Culebra.
The storm should take a sharp turn northwest, though, after churning through Puerto Rico and the Leeward Islands and stay over open waters in the Atlantic.
Heavy rainfall may result in ‘locally considerable’ flash flooding and mudslides in areas of the Leeward Islands through Tuesday and over the Virgin Islands into Puerto Rico by later Tuesday through Wednesday, according to the NHC.

title: Tropical Storm Warnings Issued For Puerto Rico , U . S . Virgin Islands
message:
Tropical Storm warnings have been issued for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as Potential Tropical Cyclone Five churns in the Atlantic Ocean.
The cyclone is forecast to strengthen into Tropical Storm Ernesto by Tuesday (August 13) as it moves west toward the Leeward Islands.
"On the forecast track, the disturbance is expected to move across portions of the Leeward Islands late tonight or Tuesday and approach the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico Tuesday evening," the National Hurricane Center said.
Meteorologists are warning the storm could bring up to ten inches of flooding rains and damaging winds to Puerto Rico before heading north and strengthening into a hurricane later in the week.
Most forecast models show the storm system will stay away from the East Coast of the U.S. as it strengthens in the mid-Atlantic.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto eyes Puerto Rico while plowing through Caribbean islands
message:
CNN —Tropical Storm Ernesto is strengthening as it slams the northern Caribbean with heavy rain, gusty winds and rough seas Tuesday and approaches Puerto Rico.
Ernesto could become a hurricane while it tracks just north of Puerto Rico early Wednesday.
Tropical Storm Ernesto moves through the northern Caribbean Tuesday afternoon.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect for Puerto Rico and the Leeward Islands, including the US and British Virgin Islands.
Rainfall totals of 4 to 6 inches will be widespread, with up to 10 inches possible in parts of Puerto Rico.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto gaining momentum as it approaches Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto has moved into the Caribbean Sea as it packs heavy rain and damaging winds and approaches the U.S. territories of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
First, it will reach the Leeward Islands Tuesday, before proceeding to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands later in the day, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect for the entire area, the NHC said.
RELATED STORY | NOAA expects 'extraordinary' 2024 Atlantic hurricane seasonAs the storm approaches, Puerto Rico has activated the National Guard and canceled classes at the start of the public school year, according to The Associated Press.
Bermuda could also get hit with the storm later in the week.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto hits Caribbean , heads to Puerto Rico
message:
By DÁNICA COTO, The Associated PressSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials shuttered schools and government agencies.
The storm was located about 300 miles east-southeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Tuesday morning.
The looming rains come as Puerto Rico faces six reservoirs that already were overflowing ahead of the storm.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.
(NOAA via AP)APThe National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to move over or near Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Targets Puerto Rico , Prompts Closures
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto struck the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday, closing schools and government agencies in Puerto Rico.
Forecasters predict six to eight inches of rain for Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands, with possible flooding and landslides, and up to 10 inches in isolated areas.
Warnings extend to Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, the US and British Virgin Islands, and other surrounding islands.
Ernesto is forecast to pass over or near Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands by Tuesday evening.
This marks the fifth named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season; it is expected to become a hurricane by Thursday over open waters while on course toward Bermuda.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto : Puerto Rico prepares – NBC 6 South Florida
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials shuttered schools and government agencies.
The storm was located about 300 miles east-southeast of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Tuesday morning.
The looming rains come as Puerto Rico faces six reservoirs that already were overflowing ahead of the storm.
The National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to move over or near Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening.
“That’s a reality,” said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto drenches northeast Caribbean and takes aim at Puerto Rico
message:
“Ernesto could be near or at hurricane strength in about 24 hours,” the US National Hurricane Centre in Miami said in an advisory late on Tuesday morning.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Anguilla, St Martin, St Barts and St Maarten.
Heavy rains began pelting Puerto Rico, and strong winds churned the ocean into a milky turquoise as people rushed to finish securing homes and businesses.
“We are going to have a lot of rain,” Puerto Rico governor Pedro Pierluisi said as he urged people to be indoors by early Tuesday evening.
Ernesto Rodriguez with the National Weather Service warned that the storm’s trajectory could change as it approaches Puerto Rico.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to hit Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands before strengthening into hurricane
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto was gaining strength as it swirled in the Atlantic Ocean Tuesday, just days after Debby finished its trek along the U.S. East Coast.
Ernesto is expected to hit near or over the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Tuesday evening, the National Hurricane Center says.
It was expected o be near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands by Tuesday evening and pass to the northeast and north of Puerto Rico Tuesday and Wednesday.
A hurricane watch is in effect for the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, and the islands Vieques and Culebra.
Satellite imagery shows Tropical Storm Ernesto on a path toward the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico on Aug. 13.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto drenches northeast Caribbean and takes aim at Puerto Rico
message:
“Ernesto could be near or at hurricane strength in about 24 hours,” the US National Hurricane Centre in Miami said in an advisory late on Tuesday morning.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Anguilla, St Martin, St Barts and St Maarten.
Heavy rains began pelting Puerto Rico, and strong winds churned the ocean into a milky turquoise as people rushed to finish securing homes and businesses.
“We are going to have a lot of rain,” Puerto Rico governor Pedro Pierluisi said as he urged people to be indoors by early Tuesday evening.
Ernesto Rodriguez with the National Weather Service warned that the storm’s trajectory could change as it approaches Puerto Rico.

title: Pee Dee residents return to flooded homes , cars after evacuating for Debby
message:
BENNETTSVILLE, S.C. (WMBF) - After leaving their homes during Tropical Storm Debby, residents returned to survey the damage left in the storm’s wake.
"I was hoping that when I come back, my house would still be standing,” said Bennettsville resident Ruby Covington.
Covington was one of many residents who evacuated when they saw the water rising during Tropical Storm Debby last week.
“The reason why we left is because the water was coming out the creek and into the yard,” said Covington.
The American Red Cross is now assisting people in the area who were most impacted by the storm and flooding.

title: Delaware River Drops Below 15 Feet , High Water Advisory Remains
message:
The Delaware River at the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area has fallen below 15 feet, leading to the reopening of the park.
However, the National Park Service (NPS) continues to enforce its High Water Advisory, requiring all individuals in the river to wear a life jacket.
The park had been closed until the river dropped below the 15-foot mark, which occurred early Sunday morning.
Despite the drop in water levels, park managers are still urging caution due to the potential for hazardous conditions.
The Delaware River and all access points had been closed due to the hazardous conditions.

title: Warnings issued for US territories as Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in Atlantic
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto gained strength into a named storm Monday afternoon in the Atlantic, where it threatens Caribbean communities with wind, rain and storm surge.
It was close to 600 miles east-southeast of Puerto Rico, moving west-northwest at 28mph.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect Monday for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
5pm AST August 12th -- Here are the latest Key Messages for now Tropical Storm #Ernesto.
Expected to bring tropical storm conditions to portions of Leeward Islands tonight & tomorrow, moving into the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by late Tuesday.

title: Gainesville begins mosquito spraying to control rising numbers after Hurricane Debby
message:
Local mosquito populations already on the rise prior to the arrival of Hurricane Debby are finding new breeding grounds in standing water left behind by the storm.
Last week, the city of Gainesville’s Mosquito Control division began spraying for mosquitoes throughout Gainesville and are expected to continue spraying this week.
For residents with retention ponds on their property, the division provides mosquito fish, free of charge.
The Mosquito Control division actively monitors and treats more than 650 breeding sites throughout Gainesville for mosquito larvae including retention ponds, roadside ditches, low-lying regions and areas prone to flooding.
This article originally appeared on The Gainesville Sun: Gainesville begins mosquito spraying after rains from Hurricane Debby

title: Tropical storm Ernesto will dry us out this weekend
message:
Tropical storm Ernesto has developed east of the NE Caribbean and is expected to slowly consolidate into a hurricane once it passes the Islands.
A storm system or trough of low pressure off the coast of the mid Atlantic coast will keep Ernesto away from the mainland of the United States.
This will bring our rain chances down to less than 20%.
This weekend the rain chances go down below 20% for the coast and only 20% inland.
Dry air settles in for the weekend due to Ernesto (WWSB)Copyright 2024 WWSB.

title: The state rep who sparked Colorado fire recovery - Grist
message:
Hello, and welcome back to State of Emergency, a limited-run newsletter about how disasters are reshaping our politics.
A focus on fireKyle Brown was the lead sponsor on 26 bills during his first term as a Colorado state representative, and half of those concerned either the Marshall Fire recovery or future fire resilience.
The hurricane also brought flooding to Tampa as early voting began in Florida state primaries.
Read moreTim Walz, climate veep: Minnesota governor Tim Walz hails from a state that is immune from many big climate disasters, such as hurricanes and wildfires.
But as my State of Emergency co-writer reports, Kamala Harris’ running mate has an impressive record of passing big green laws in his purple state.

title: The Future is Uninsurable ? Hardly
message:
Insure our Future is backed by the Connecticut Citizens Action Group, whose mission statement is to “actively engage the residents of Connecticut in altering the relations of power in order to bring about environmental, economic, and social justice.”The “uninsurable future” crowd is mainly on the left, but needn’t be.
Analysis to determine whether or not the future is uninsurable presupposes that we know what the future will hold.
But there is data to support the contention that, whatever the future brings, it does not constitute an existential threat to the insurance industry.
Insurance Capital and Alternative CapitalThe property and casualty insurance industry had $2.7 trillion in assets at year-end 2023.
The federal government has already botched its management of two insurance programs – federal flood insurance and crop insurance.

title: Nankei Trough advisory : Japan is bracing for a once - in - a - century earthquake . Does it need to ?
message:
A special committee warned that another “major earthquake” could hit in the coming week – the first time in its history the body had issued this type of nationwide advisory.
Then there’s the looming threat of the Nankai Trough megathrust earthquake – the most powerful of its kind, with magnitudes that can exceed 9.
Japan’s government has warned of the possible Nankai Trough quake for so many years that the possibility of it occurring has become common knowledge.
The ‘big one’The Nankai Trough is a 700-kilometer long (435-mile) subduction zone, which refers to when tectonic plates slip beneath each other.
“I tell (my students), the Nankai Trough earthquake will definitely come, whether it’s your generation or your children’s generation,” he said.

title: It so bad and so heartbreaking : River flooding affecting Pee Dee homeowners after Debby
message:
MARION COUNTY, SC (WMBF) -The town of Nichols continues to cope with the aftereffects of Tropical Storm Debby.
Rogers said the town had an opportunity to get ahead of some of the issues with flooding with preventative measures.
Down the road, Bernice Britt is used to traveling the Little Pee Dee River in a boat but is now wading through the water in her front yard.
After consulting a few friends, Britt said she decided to self-evacuate as the river continues to rise.
The WMBF First Alert Weather Team continues to monitor the river levels, the latest details can be found here.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto drenches northeast Caribbean and takes aim at Puerto Rico
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto batters northeast Caribbean and aims at Puerto Rico as it strengthensTropical Storm Ernesto batters northeast Caribbean and aims at Puerto Rico as it strengthens View PhotoSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Tropical Storm Ernesto battered the northeast Caribbean on Tuesday as it took aim at Puerto Rico, where officials closed schools, opened shelters and moved dozens of the U.S. territory’s endangered parrots into hurricane-proof rooms.
Tropical storm warnings were in place for Puerto Rico, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Anguilla, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.

message:
As tremors shook the ground in parts of western Japan last Thursday, local and national government bodies leapt into action.
Meteorologists gathered and issued a temporary tsunami advisory.
A special committee warned that another “major earthquake” could hit in the coming week – the first time in its history the body had issued... read full story"Japan sits on the boundaries of four tectonic plates, which makes it one of the most earthquake-prone areas in the world,"

title: Another tropical storm forms in Atlantic , threatens Puerto Rico
message:
By DÁNICA COTO Associated PressSAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Puerto Rico activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect for Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.
Officials in the French Caribbean said the storm was expected to drench Guadeloupe on Monday and pass near St. Barts and St. Martin.
The National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to move over or near Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has predicted an above-average Atlantic hurricane season this year because of record warm ocean temperatures.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to strengthen into a hurricane on path to Bermuda
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto will be bringing heavy rain, strong winds and rough surf to Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands in the next two days before strengthening into a hurricane and curving north and east toward Bermuda by this weekend, forecasters said.
Tropical storm warnings — indicating tropical storm conditions are expected within 36 hours — are active in Anguilla, Antigua, Barbuda, Barthelemy, Culebra, Guadeloupe, Montserrat, Nevis, St. Barthelemy, St. Kitts, St. Martin, Sint Maarten, the British Virgin Islands, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and Vieques.
“On the forecast track, Ernesto is expected to move across portions of the Leeward Islands this morning and near or over the U.S. and British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by this evening,” the hurricane center said in its latest storm advisory.
“After passing Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, Ernesto is forecast to turn northward over the western Atlantic,” the agency added.
As of now, Ernesto — which strengthened into a tropical storm Monday evening and became the fifth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season — is not expected to have any direct impacts on the eastern United States.

title: We Have Tropical Storm Ernesto : The Alabama Weather Blog
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto has now officially formed, with a center of circulation and deep convection gradually organizing in bands around the storm.
WARNINGS——–The current warnings in effect for Tropical Storm Ernesto include:– Tropical Storm Warnings are in effect for St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barthelemy, Sint Maarten, the British Virgin Islands, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Vieques, and Culebra.
These warnings indicate that tropical storm conditions are expected within these areas within the next 36 hours.
Residents in these areas should prepare for tropical storm conditions, including strong winds, heavy rainfall, potential flash flooding, and storm surge impacts.
BERMUDA——-Bermuda is expected to experience a major impact from Tropical Storm Ernesto, with the most severe conditions forecasted for Saturday, August 17th.

title: Get ready for more wildfires and hurricanes : Environment Canada
message:
Human-caused climate change is making heat waves much more likely, the federal government says, bringing extreme weather from fires to storms.
That's according to Environment and Climate Change Canada's rapid extreme weather event attribution system, which compares today's climate to a pre-industrial one.
Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson said there will be more wildfires from British Columbia to Manitoba this month, with climate change fuelling them.
"It is not unusual for Western Canada to see high levels of fire activity this time of year," he said at a press conference on Monday.
Get ready for more floods, fires and hurricanes as climate change clobbers Canada.

title: Lahaina wildfire anniversary highlights need for consistent , long - term , disaster recovery coverage by national TV news
message:
The Lahaina wildfire, which started on August 8, 2023, devastated the historic town of Lahaina, Hawaii, on Maui’s coast, claiming over 100 lives and destroying more than 2,000 structures.
As one of the deadliest wildfires in recent U.S. history, it left the community grappling with immense loss and facing significant challenges in recovery.
The fire exacerbated pre-existing issues like housing shortages and economic dependence on tourism while also highlighting the region's vulnerability to climate-related disasters.
The disaster has also raised concerns about how to preserve Lahaina's rich cultural heritage during the rebuilding process.
The community is actively involved in discussions about Lahaina's future, with a focus on honoring its cultural history and improving resilience against future disasters.

title: Japan is bracing for a once - in - a - century earthquake
message:
A special committee warned that another “major earthquake” could hit in the coming week – the first time in its history the body had issued this type of nationwide advisory.
Then there’s the looming threat of the Nankai Trough megathrust earthquake – the most powerful of its kind, with magnitudes that can exceed 9.
Japan’s government has warned of the possible Nankai Trough quake for so many years that the possibility of it occurring has become common knowledge.
The Nankai Trough is a 700-kilometer long (435-mile) subduction zone, which refers to when tectonic plates slip beneath each other.
“I tell (my students), the Nankai Trough earthquake will definitely come, whether it’s your generation or your children’s generation,” he said.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto expected to strengthen into a hurricane by Thursday
message:
SAN JUAN – Tropical Storm Ernesto on Tuesday threatened to bring heavy rainfall, dangerous storm surges and strong winds to the US, British Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, leading the US territory to close schools and prepare for power outages.
The storm, last observed northwest of the island of Guadalupe and carrying maximum winds of 45 miles per hour (75 km per hour), could strengthen into a hurricane by Thursday after passing over Puerto Rico and veering north into the Atlantic, the National Hurricane Center said.
Ernesto – the fifth named storm of the season – is expected to miss Florida and the US Southeast, which are still reeling from Tropical Storm Debby.
Like Debby, Ernesto’s greatest threat is torrential rain, which could spur flash floods and landslides, especially in the mountainous interior of Puerto Rico and nearby Caribbean islands.
On Monday, Puerto Rico Governor Pedro Pierluisi activated more than 200 National Guard members and expedited food benefits for families ahead of the storm’s arrival.

title: 4 . 4 magnitude earthquake hits Los Angeles area
message:
A powerful earthquake struck near Los Angeles, California on Monday afternoon, shaking homes and startling residents for miles.
The 4.4 magnitude quake's epicentre hit near Highland Park, a neighbourhood in Los Angeles County not far from the famous Hollywood sign and the Griffith Observatory, at around 12:20 PST (20:20 BST), according to the US Geological Survey.
The Los Angeles Fire Department said crews from the city's 106 fire stations were doing a complete survey of the Greater Los Angeles area for structural damage or other issues.
The earthquake was first estimated as a 4.7 magnitude, but was later downgraded to a 4.4 magnitude by the US Geological Survey.
The area has seen several magnitude 4 and 5 earthquakes in recent weeks, including in Grapevine and Bakersfield, California last week.

message:

title: Puerto Rico Braces for Tropical Storm Ernesto | 96 . 3 | 102 . 5 NewsRadio WFLA
message:
Puerto Rico has activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect for Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
Ernesto's maximum sustained winds are 45 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center.
The storm is expected to spin out into the central Atlantic away from the US Mainland.

title: Canadians should be prepared for more wildfires and hurricanes : Environment Canada | iNFOnews
message:
Canadians should be prepared for more wildfires and hurricanes: Environment CanadaBurnt buses and cars in Jasper, Alta., on July 26, 2024.
That's according to Environment and Climate Change Canada's rapid extreme weather event attribution system, which compares today's climate to a pre-industrial one.
THE CANADIAN PRESS/Amber BrackenOTTAWA - Human-caused climate change is making heat waves much more likely, the federal government says, bringing extreme weather from fires to storms.
That's according to Environment and Climate Change Canada's rapid extreme weather event attribution system, which compares today's climate to a pre-industrial one.
Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson said there will be more wildfires from British Columbia to Manitoba this month, with climate change fuelling them.

title: Light earthquake , 4 . 4 mag has occurred near Saga in China
message:
A light earthquake with magnitude 4.4 (ml/mb) was reported 178 km ENE of Saga, China (111 miles) on Thursday.
The 4.4-magnitude earthquake has occurred at 10:05:29 / 10:05 am (local time epicenter).
The earthquake was roughly at a depth of 10 km (6 miles).
Ids that are associated to the earthquake: us7000mzz2.
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: 178 km ENE of Saga, China.

title: Light earthquake , 4 . 5 mag has occurred near Ollagüe in Chile
message:
A light earthquake magnitude 4.5 (ml/mb) has occurred on Tuesday, 58 km SW of Ollagüe, Chile (36 miles).
Id of earthquake: us6000nju3.
The earthquake occurred at a depth of 125.453 km (78 miles).
A tsunami warning has not been issued (Does not indicate if a tsunami actually did or will exist).
Read more about the earthquake, Seismometer information, Date-Time, Location, Distances, Parameters and details about this quake, recorded: 58 km SW of Ollagüe, Chile.
